title: When restricting an associated type, suggested code doesn't respect modules

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-papercut
labels.description: Diagnostic error that needs small tweaks

labels.name: D-invalid-suggestion
labels.description: A structured suggestion resulting in incorrect code

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur.
-->

Given the following code: (https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=c76624704206f023ab0e28dfe0a097c2)

```rust
mod foo {
    pub trait X {
        type Y;
        fn get() -> Self::Y;
    }
}

fn needs_clone<T: Clone>(t: T) {}

fn bar<T: foo::X>() {
    needs_clone(T::get());
}
```

The current output is:

```
...
help: consider further restricting the associated type
   |
10 | fn bar<T: foo::X>() where <T as X>::Y: Clone {
   |                     ++++++++++++++++++++++++
...
```

<!-- The following is not always necessary. -->
Ideally the output should look like:

```
...
help: consider further restricting the associated type
   |
10 | fn bar<T: foo::X>() where <T as foo::X>::Y: Clone {
   |                     +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
...
```

since otherwise rust's suggestion doesn't compile. It's worth noting that when suggesting trait bounds, modules are respected: (https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=5d72d2bd60929e6a7ec1207de90f9c7a)

```
mod foo {
    pub trait X {}
}

fn needs_x<T: foo::X>() {}

fn bar<T>() {
    needs_x::<T>();
}
```

```
...
help: consider restricting type parameter `T`
  |
7 | fn bar<T: foo::X>() {
  |         ++++++++
...
```

<!--
If dramatically different output is caused by small changes, consider also
adding them here.

If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions. The output might also be
different depending on the Edition.
-->
